description.narrative: The projects overall objective is to mobilise youths energy, mobility, open-mindedness and dynamism as a potential positive force of countering violent extremist influences and narratives in the target communities affected by radicalisation.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Output 1.2 Youth Action Plans in 10 communities in Kyrgyz Republic with high risk of radicalisation 1.2.1 Number of Youth Action Groups formed - 10 1.2.2 Number of youth benefited from trainings on civic participation, leadership and participatory assessment - 1000 1.2.3 An analysis of gaps, challenges and opportunities for youth participation and inclusion in decision making process - 10 1.2.4. Number of local self-government groups where Youth Action Plans are institutionalised and small grants provided for implementation - 2
Output 2.2 Enhancing job and income opportunities through peer-to-peer support groups and mentorship for at least 500 young people in 10 selected districts with high risk of radicalisation in Kyrgyz Republic 2.2.1 An analysis on potential employment and youth entrepreneurship opportunities to be conducted - 0 2.2.2 Number of adjusted or developed training courses, mentorship programmes and/or curricula - 0 2.2.3 Number of youth benefitted from training, mentorship and apprenticeship programmes and business start-up weekends - 0 2.2.4 Number of sustainable jobs created through small grants programme - 0 2.2.5 Number of job fairs, business forums and other networking events - 0

Output 1.2 Youth Action Plans in 10 communities in Kyrgyz Republic with high risk of radicalisation 1.2.1 Number of Youth Action Groups formed - 0 1.2.2 Number of youth benefited from trainings on civic participation, leadership and participatory assessment - 0 1.2.3 An analysis of gaps, challenges and opportunities for youth participation and inclusion in decision making process - 0 1.2.4. Number of local self-government groups where Youth Action Plans are institutionalised and small grants provided for implementation - 0
Output 2.2 Enhancing job and income opportunities through peer-to-peer support groups and mentorship for at least 500 young people in 10 selected districts with high risk of radicalisation in Kyrgyz Republic 2.2.1 An analysis on potential employment and youth entrepreneurship opportunities to be conducted - 0 2.2.2 Number of adjusted or developed training courses, mentorship programmes and/or curricula - 0 2.2.3 Number of youth benefitted from training, mentorship and apprenticeship programmes and business start-up weekends - 0 2.2.4 Number of sustainable jobs created through small grants programme - 0 2.2.5 Number of job fairs, business forums and other networking events - 0

Output 1: At-risk youth have access to and actively participate in ‘safe’ engagement platforms to foster positive alternative to extremist narratives, and develop a greater sense of belonging and peer-to-peer support 1.2.1: 10 YAGs formed 1.2.4: 10 LSGs where Youth Action Plans are institutionalized, and small grants provided for implementation
Output 2. Utilizing youth engagement platforms and support structures, youth will benefit from group-based skills- and entrepreneurship development services.
2.2.3: 100 youth benefitted from training, mentorship and apprenticeship programmes and business start-up weekends 2.2.4: 10 sustainable jobs created through small grant programme 2.2.5: 2 job fairs, business forums and other networking events

Major achievements under Output 1.2:
 Needs and priorities of youth assessed in 10 pilot municipalities.  Favorable conditions have been created for the involvement of young people in social and economic life of the local communities by creating 10 Youth Centers with appropriate buildings, fully equipped and renovated\constructed. To ensure the work of these Centers, 10 youth groups have been created whose members are about 100 local youth activists. These Centers operate based on the developed standard regulations, which were approved and adopted by the executive bodies of the pilot LSGs.  4,000 young people trained on legal issues, social skills, conflict management and entrepreneurship.  Together with LSGs, local youth groups, as well as with the support of implementing partners, local youth development plans have been developed in pilot communities. In total, 92 youth took an active part in the processes of developing plans and their further promotion. 8 youth development plans have been approved, adopted by local councils of deputies and received financial support from the local budget of $100,000.
Major achievements under Output 2.2:
 Together with local implementing Partners UNDP allocated $270,000 to support youth social and startup initiatives through establishing a Revolving Fund. This mechanism allows to support the business initiatives of young people on a sustainable basis. The returned funds will again be used to support a new/next funding cycle for startups and youth entrepreneurship projects.  25 project proposals were supported: startups and local youth social initiatives, as part of the local youth action plans. Projects are mainly in the field of provision services to the population, livestock and production, also there are education, social support, and current Covid-19 response measures lead by local youth action groups.  In total, 113 jobs were created.  12 open online courses for young people have been developed on topical issues of career guidance, self-employment, collaboration strategies, etc. Each video has an average of 500 views at the time of the course is launched.

Output 1: UNDP hired Institute for Youth development (CSO) for implementing the following activities of the project: 1) Activity 1.2.1. Youth Action Groups (YAGs) with participation of youth, local authorities, civic society, religious and community leaders / organizations are formed to enhance youth participation in local development agendas and raise awareness on risks of radicalisation - 10 YAGs formed 2) Activity 1.2.2. Capacity of youth action groups members (YAGs) has been strengthened through trainings on leadership, civic engagement, communication and public monitoring to ensure the effective development and implementation of youth action plans (YAPs) - at least 100 young men and women (10 persons in each YAG) trained 3) Activity 1.2.3. A joint analysis was conducted by youth action groups (YAGs) to identify gaps and contradictions as well as opportunities for youth participation in decision-making processes for the development of Youth Action Plans (YAPs)-10 LSGs through NGO or Local Consultants 4) Activity 1.2.4. Youth Action Plans (YAPs) have been developed and integrated into the existing development plans of local self-government bodies to solve the problems of youth and expand its participation in local development processes-10 LSGs
Output 2: 1) Activity 2.2.1. An analysis on potencial employment and youth entrepreneurship opportunities conducted - 1 2) Activity 2.2.2. Number of adjusted or developed training courses, mentorship programmes and/or curriculums - 1 3) Activity 2.2.3. Number of youth benefitted from training,mentorship and apprenticeship programmes and business start-up weekends-100 4) Activity 2.2.4. Number of sustaibanble jobs created through small grant programme -10 5) Activity 2.2.5. Number of job fairs, business forums and other networking events - 2

Major achievements under Output 1.2: • Baseline survey conducted based on 10 focus group discussions among youth and 10 focus group discussions among municipal staff covering 110 participants, 541 questionnaires filled out and informal observation conducted (implemented in 2018). • Needs and priorities of youth assessed in 10 pilot municipalities (implemented in 2018). • 24 youth leaders completed a 6-month intensive ‘Dilgir’ course on April 18, 2019 and obtained certificates issued by the Ministry of Education and Science of the KR. • 20 staff of pilot municipalities completed a 6-month intensive course for Specialists on Youth Affairs on April 2, 2019 and obtained certificates issued by the Academy of Public Administration under the President of KR. Jointly with the Staff of pilot municipalities the youth leaders developed so called ‘portfolios’ (i.e. individual youth action plans) and conducted 64 events covering around 3,000 participants. This is a good example of interaction of the youth leaders with the municipal servants and will be used further in development and adoption of local strategies on youth policies that will be a part of the Programme on Social-Economic Development adopted in June 2019 and will be valid for the next 4 years and for implementation of which funding from local budgets will be allocated. • ‘Safe Route’ interactive game among youth piloted in 10 municipalities among youth aged between 14-28 on May 14-28, 2019 and covered more than 400 people. • Together with LSGs, local youth groups, as well as with the support of implementing partners, local youth development plans have been developed in pilot communities. At this stage, 8 plans have been developed and adopted, 1 plan is being at the adoption stage. In total, 92 youth (75% male and 25% female) took an active part in the processes of developing plans and their further promotion. The indicated 8 youth development plans have been approved, adopted by local councils of deputies and received full financial support from the local budget for a total of more than $188,000.
Major achievements under Output 2.2: • Together with local IP UNDP KG allocated $100,000 to support various youth initiatives through establishing a Revolving Fund. On the other hand, the IP reached agreement with a respective Commercial Bank to be a partner and allocate relatively the same amount to credit youth initiatives with low interest rate and without collateral. This will leverage external investments/funding opportunities to support youth initiatives. The grant funding among youth is already launched. • In total, 53 project proposals were received under the revolving fund, a specially created commission selected and awarded financing to 21 projects for a total of $ 100,000. Projects are mainly in the field of provision services to the population, livestock and production. In total, 112 jobs were created (78% male and 22% female, as well as 2 people with disabilities (PWDs) and 12 young people from vulnerable categories). About $7,000 of the funds issued has already been returned according to the agreement, respectively, these funds will be issued to young people from the reserve list of projects or from the number of new applications that have already begun to come. • The second round of call was announced among CSOs approximately for $100,000 to support youth initiatives, which is ongoing.
